Description: Wall fragment of Attic pottery shallow cup-skyphos; glaze mostly fired orange-brown and flaked off in parts; interior glazed; exterior: large, roughly drawn palmette and part of male figure (in silhouette) bending over to right, extending his right arm in the direction of a rounded object (probably a krater); below, horizontal band as ground line; lower part of bowl glazed. Drill hole in broken edge from sampling for analysis.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The clay was analysed by M. Hughes and found to be Attic: Harbottle, G., Hughes, M. J. and Seleem, S. 'The Origin of black-figure Greek ceramics found in Naucratis (Nile Delta)', Archaeometry 47, 2005, 511-8; p.513, table 1, no.1
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1528)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
